query: Tell me about Indigenous land stewardship in Brazil\

nodes.label: Geosynthetics
nodes.description: Geosynthetics are human-made products used to stabilize terrain.

nodes.label: Flood-proof sanitary latrines
nodes.description: Overflowing of sanitary latrines during flood events poses a serious health risk to communities in flood prone areas. The contaminated water may infiltrate surface or groundwater sources, causing pollution and disease. Improved construction design and planning of latrines can minimize these risks. Measures include elevating latrines or lining latrine pits to reduce waste infiltration and increase stability.

nodes.label: Drought-resistant crops
nodes.description: Drought-resistant crops are varieties of plants that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand prolonged periods of low water availability.

nodes.label: Light detection and ranging
nodes.description: Light Detection and Ranging is a remote sensing method that uses light in the form of a pulsed laser to measure ranges (variable distances) to the Earth. These light pulses, combined with other data recorded by the airborne system, generate precise, three-dimensional information about the shape of the Earth and its surface characteristics.

nodes.label: Groynes
nodes.description: A groyne is a rigid hydraulic structure built from an ocean shore (in coastal engineering) or from a bank (in rivers) that interrupts water flow and limits the movement of sediment. It is placed perpendicularly to the shore to trap sediments.

nodes.label: Permeable parking lots
nodes.description: Permeable pavements and parking lots are often constructed in urban settings to facilitate storm water runoff and mitigate urban flooding and storm water overflow risks. The permeable surfaces provide greater water uptake. The water is infiltrated, and to an extent purified, before recharging the groundwater. The resulting retention decreases runoff rates and reduces pressures on urban storm water systems.

nodes.label: Storm drains
nodes.description: A storm drain is part of the urban storm management system. It is an infrastructure designed to drain excess rain and ground water from impermeable surfaces and prevent or minimise flooding events.

nodes.label: Drip irrigation
nodes.description: Drip irrigation involves dripping water onto the soil at very low rates (2-20 litres/hour) from a system of small diameter plastic pipes fitted with outlets called emitters or drippers. Water is applied close to plants so that only part of the soil in which the roots grow is wetted. Drip irrigation can provide asmuch as 90 per cent water-use efficiency and has been applied in arid and semi-aridzones as well as in areas with irregular flows of water.

nodes.label: Water recycling and reclamation
nodes.description: Water recycling and reclamation is an approach that considers to consider municipal wastewater as a vital resource for appropriate applications, including agricultural and other irrigation, industrial and domestic uses.

nodes.label: ecosystem monitoring
nodes.description: Ecosystem monitoring refers to the systematic observation and assessment of ecosystems to track changes, understand ecological processes, and evaluate the health of environmental systems over time. This process often employs various tools and technologies to gather data and supports policymaking.

nodes.label: Interbasin transfers
nodes.description: Interbasin transfer refers to projects that transport water from one waterbasin or catchment area to another via canals, tunnels, bridges, or stream flow rerouting to usually address water scarcity.

nodes.label: Bushfire reduction
nodes.description: "Bushfire reduction" refers to efforts and strategies aimed at minimizing the risk, frequency, and severity of bushfires. One strategy is the 'firebreaks', which purpose is to prevent forest fires from spreading before they damage the ecosystem, cropland or personal property. It consists in creating cleared areas to stop or slow the spread of bushfires.

nodes.label: Flood hazard mapping
nodes.description: Flood hazard assessment and mapping is used to identify areas at risk of flooding, and consequently to improve flood risk management and disaster preparedness. Flood Hazard Mapping is a vital component for appropriate land use planning in flood-prone areas. It creates easily-read, rapidly-accessible charts and maps which facilitate the identification of areas at risk of flooding.

nodes.label: Decentralised energy transmission
nodes.description: Decentralised energy systems aim to place power generation closer to the consumers. Since end users are distributed across a region, generating energy in a decentralised way can help minimise transmission and distribution losses, along with their associated economic and environmental costs.

nodes.label: Seasonal to interannual weather forecast
nodes.description: This technology allows for a forecast of weather conditions for a period of three to six months ahead. Seasonal forecasts are based on existing climate data; in particular, on sea surface temperatures, which are then used in ocean-atmosphere dynamic models, coupled with the synthesis of physically plausible national and international models.

nodes.label: Dune construction and stabilisation
nodes.description: Dune construction, strengthening and rehabilitation measures intend to restore the sand barrier functions of dunes to gain coastal protection benefits. Artificial dunes are engineered structures created to mimic the functioning of natural dunes aimed at reducing both coastal erosion and flooding in adjacent coastal lowlands.

nodes.label: Alternative sustainable feeds
nodes.description: Alternative sustainable feeds refer to non-traditional, environmentally friendly feed options for livestock that reduce the reliance on conventional grains and forages, which can be resource-intensive to produce.

nodes.label: Resilient port infrastructure
nodes.description: Port resilience is the ability to maintain an acceptable level of service in the face of disruptions. Ports' resilience is largely determined by their ability to remain operational and offer services and infrastructure to ships, cargoes, and other customers during disruptions.

nodes.label: Forested catchments protection
nodes.description: Forested catchments protection refers to the practice of preserving and managing forested areas within a catchment (or watershed) to maintain the health and function of the entire ecosystem. A catchment is the area of land where all precipitation collects and drains into a common outlet, such as a river, lake, or reservoir.

nodes.label: climate tolerant livestock
nodes.description: Climate-tolerant livestock refers to animals that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand challenging environmental conditions caused by climate change.

nodes.label: Biodiversity management systems
nodes.description: Biodiversity management systems (BMS) refer to organised frameworks or strategies designed to conserve and protect biodiversity in a given area, while also ensuring that human activities and development do not negatively impact ecosystems. These systems integrate environmental, social, and economic aspects to maintain or enhance biodiversity.

nodes.label: surface rupture
nodes.description: Surface rupture occurs when movement on a fault deep within the earth breaks through to the surface.

nodes.label: Revetments
nodes.description: A revetment is a slope consisting of loose or interlocking protection units (geotextiles may also be used). Revetments typically protect a soft landform such as a dune area or coastal slope.

nodes.label: Non-revenue water reduction
nodes.description: Non-revenue water is the difference between the volume input to a municipal distribution system (e.g. from a treatment plant) and the billed authorized consumption (e.g. water for which the utility receives payment), in other words, is the water that is pumped and then lost or unaccounted that could have otherwise been sold. If the water losses in developing countries could be halved, the saved water would be enough to supply around 90 million people.

nodes.label: indigenous people
nodes.description: Social and cultural groups that share collective ancestral ties to the lands and natural resources where they live, occupy or from which they have been displaced

nodes.label: Active motion-damping systems
nodes.description: Active motion-dampening systems are automated mooring systems that serve alongside or in place of traditional mooring techniques. They can help to minimize the movement of the ship when it is at port, adjusting automatically to tidal changes, swells, or other shifts in the sea level.

nodes.label: technologies
nodes.description: Human-created methods for extending agency.

nodes.label: Prescribed fire
nodes.description: Prescribed fire is a form of land management in which fire is intentionally applied to vegetation. Prescribed fires are conducted under desired conditions to meet specific objectives, such as to restore fire regimes in adapted ecosystems or to limit the amount of dry brush in an area prone to wildfires.

nodes.label: Water accounting
nodes.description: Water accounting is the systematic study of the current status and trends in water supply, demand, accessibility and use. Water accounting provides the foundation of sound water management decisions.

nodes.label: Climate scenario development
nodes.description: Climate scenarios often make use of climate projections by manipulating model outputs and combining them with observed climate data. To develop such scenarios various scenario construction methods are used, such as climate model based approaches,temporal and spatial analogues, incremental scenarios for sensitivity studies, and expert judgement.

nodes.label: Storm surge barriers and closure dams
nodes.description: Storm surge barriers and closure dams are hard engineered structures with the primary function of preventing coastal flooding. Storm surge barriers are movable or fixed barriers or gates that are closed to prevent flooding when an extreme water level is forecast. Closure dams are fixed structures that permanently close off a river mouth or estuary.

nodes.label: Ecological buffer zones
nodes.description: Buffer zones are designated areas used to protect sensitive landscape patches (e.g., wetlands, wildlife reserves) o lessen the impacts of human activity and land disturbance.

nodes.label: Dikes
nodes.description: A dike is a structure made of earth or stone that's used to hold back water.

nodes.label: geohazard
nodes.description: Geohazards are adverse geological phenomenon's that are capable of causing widespread damage or loss to property, life and the environment, such as earthquakes, volcano eruptions and tsunamis.

nodes.label: soil liquefaction
nodes.description: Soil liquefaction occurs when soil is transformed from a solid to a liquid state as a result of increased pore pressure and reduced effective stress. It is typically caused by rapid loading of the soil during earthquake shaking.

nodes.label: flow-through dam
nodes.description: The flow-through dam is designed for the sole purpose of flood control, just one of the many possible functions of dams. An opening (spillway) is designed into the dam at about the same height as the river bed, so the structure is intended to let water flow through during normal times.

nodes.label: Adaptation technologies
nodes.description: Adaptation technologies are systems, tools, processes and innovations that facilitate the process of adjusting to and managing the current and future effects of climate change.

nodes.label: Hydrological modelling
nodes.description: A hydrologic model is a simplification of a real-world system (e.g., surface water, soil water, wetland, groundwater, estuary) that aids in understanding, predicting, and managing water resources. Both the flow and quality of water are commonly studied using hydrologic models.

nodes.label: Windbreaks
nodes.description: Windbreaks are linear plantings of trees and shrubs designed to provide economic, environmental and community benefits. The primary purpose of most windbreaks is to slow the wind which creates a more beneficial condition for soils, crops, livestock, wildlife and people.

nodes.label: Riverine flood protection
nodes.description: A fluvial (riverine) flood is a rise, usually brief, in the water level of a stream or water body to a peak from which the water level recedes at a slower rate. Riverine flood protection refers to a set of measures and strategies designed to prevent or mitigate the impacts of flooding in areas adjacent to rivers.

nodes.label: Sprinkler irrigation
nodes.description: Sprinkler irrigation is a type of pressurised irrigation that consists of applying water to the soil surface using mechanical and hydraulic devices that simulate natural rainfall. Sprinkler irrigation technology can support farmers to adapt to climate change by making more efficient use of their water supply.

nodes.label: seismogenic hazards
nodes.description: A seismic hazard is the probability that an earthquake will occur in a given geographic area, within a given window of time, and with ground motion intensity exceeding a given threshold

nodes.label: soil moisture monitoring
nodes.description: Soil moisture is the amount of water in the soil. It is linked to the water cycle and is affected by both weather and climate patterns. It is also a vital component of the overall composition of ecosystems, affecting biodiversity. Accurate monitoring of soil moisture is therefore essential for understanding and managing environmental and societal challenges such as agricultural dynamics and biodiversity monitoring.

nodes.label: Indigenous water storage structures
nodes.description: Indigenous knowledge have developed over time by communities. It is a body of knowledge based on experience and not confined to tribal groups. Communities in arid and semi-arid areas have relied on indigenous knowledge to harvest rain water providing water as supplement, to increase crop yield and reduce the risk of crop failure. Indigenous RWH combine technical efficiency with low cost and acceptability to the local farmers.

nodes.label: crop diversification and new varieties
nodes.description: Crop diversification refers to the practice of growing a variety of different crops on the same agricultural land, rather than focusing on a single crop. This strategy is used to reduce the risks associated with farming, such as those caused by pests, diseases, or unpredictable weather patterns. It also helps improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide a more stable income for farmers.

nodes.label: Wastewater irrigation
nodes.description: Reusing water from urban waste water treatment plants can help address water scarcity. It can ensure a safe and predictable source of water, whilst lowering the pressure on water bodies and thereby preserving water resources. Farmers can use this water for irrigation, helping the preservation of water resources and adapting to climate change.

nodes.label: Fungal symbioses
nodes.description: It is a symbiotic relationship between a fungus and a photosynthetic bacteria or algae. The cells from the alga or bacterium live inside the fungus. Besides providing a home, the fungus also provides nutrients. In turn, the bacterium or the alga provides energy to the fungus by performing photosynthesis.

nodes.label: adaptation
nodes.description: The process of adjusting to living in a changing climate. This can include altering behaviour, systems, and ways of life to reduce or avoid both current and future harms from climate impacts.

nodes.label: GPS
nodes.description: GPS is a satellite-based navigation system that allows users to determine their precise location (latitude, longitude, and altitude) anywhere on Earth. The system is widely used for navigation, mapping, timing and therefore can give precise real-time information playing an important role to  foresee and respond to natural disasters.

nodes.label: Integrated nutrient management
nodes.description: Integrated Nutrient Management refers to the maintenance of soil fertility and of plant nutrient supply at an optimum level for sustaining the desired productivity through optimization of the benefits from all possible sources of organic, inorganic and biological components in an integrated manner.

nodes.label: Multi-purpose dams
nodes.description: Multipurpose dams combine two or more functions of traditional single-purpose dams into one hydro infrastructure project.  A multipurpose dam may combine storing and supplying water for irrigation, industry and human consumption with other uses such as flood control, power generation, navigation, run-off storage and water discharge regulation.

nodes.label: fault scarp
nodes.description: A fault scarp is a surface expression of a fault that has shifted the ground surface, ranging from small slopes to high rock escarpments

nodes.label: Water treatment
nodes.description: Water treatment is a process involving different types of operations (physical, chemical, physicochemical and biological), the aim of which is to eliminate and/or reduce contamination or non-desirable characteristics of water.

nodes.label: Soilless agriculture
nodes.description: Soilless agriculture refers to agricultural practices that grow plants without the use of traditional soil.

nodes.label: subsidence
nodes.description: Subsidence is a general term for downward vertical movement of the Earth's surface, which can be caused by both natural processes and human activities.

nodes.label: Water purification systems
nodes.description: A process or set of processes used to remove contaminants, impurities, and harmful substances from water to make it safe for drinking and other uses. This may involve filtration, chemical treatments, and other methods to improve water quality.

nodes.label: ground settlement
nodes.description: A settlement is defined as the vertical movement of the ground, generally caused be changes in stresses within the earth.

nodes.label: Grid resilience
nodes.description: The ability of a power system to resist, respond, and recover from a catastrophic event - such as environmental disasters - are key factors commonly used to define the resilience of the power system. Resilience measures reduce damage from outages and hasten restoration and recovery to shorten outage durations. .

nodes.label: climate-resilient forest management
nodes.description: Climate-Resilient Forest Management focuses on enhancing forest health to reduce risks associated with rising temperatures, shifting hydrological conditions, storms, fires, and pest outbreaks. It involves the diversification of trees' ages and species to reduce vulnerability.

nodes.label: Groundwater extraction and monitoring
nodes.description: Groundwater prospecting involves various methods to locate suitable quality and quantity groundwater for extraction. Groundwater prospecting and extraction can both be part of general water resource management strategies to increase supply, or respond to climate change induced water scarcity or variability.

nodes.label: Reduced impact logging
nodes.description: Logging techniques that result in significantly less damage to the surrounding forest and forest ecosystem. Examples of RIL include directional felling, trimming of inter-crown vines, and careful road planning.

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 6
nodes.description: SDG6: clean water and sanitation

nodes.label: Marine monitoring
nodes.description: Marine monitoring can be defined as the systematic measurement of biotic and abiotic parameters of the marine environment, with predefined spatial and temporal schedule, having the purpose to provide the data to allow assessment to classify a marine area as reaching or failing to reach Good Environmental Status.

nodes.label: fissure
nodes.description: A fissure is a long, narrow crack or linear opening in the Earth's crust.

nodes.label: Beach nourishment
nodes.description: Beach nourishment or replenishment is the artificial placement of sand on an eroded shore to maintain the amount of sand present in the foundation of the coast, and this way to compensate for natural erosion and to a greater or lesser extent protect the area against storm surge.

nodes.label: Geographic Information Systems
nodes.description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are systems designed to capture, store, manipulate,analyze, manage, and present spatial or geographic data. . The primary purpose of GIS is to allow for the visualization, analysis, and interpretation of data to understand relationships, patterns, and trends. Geographic Information Systems (GIS) play a pivotal role in enhancing disaster management and planning in risk assessment, emergency response and recovery efforts.

nodes.label: Flood-proof wells
nodes.description: Flooding of wells often results in contamination of freshwater. Specialised construction design and planning procedures can be used to protect wells against the risks of flooding, and consequent water contamination. Specific measures can mitigate contaminant infiltration and improve the well’s strength, reducing the risk of collapse during a flooding event.

nodes.label: Control of sand encroachment
nodes.description: The fundamental principle of dune fixation is that of preventing sand from moving during a long enough period to allow natural or planted vegetation to become established. If sand encroachment is to be controlled, saltation must be reduced, either by stabilizing the soil or by reducing the wind speed gradient close to the surface of the ground.

nodes.label: Vulnerability assessment tools
nodes.description: Climate change vulnerability assessments evaluate how climate change will impact a specific system (e.g., a river basin, water sector, country, or city). These assessments go beyond the exposure (e.g. rainfall) by also considering the system's characteristics (sensitivity) and its ability to adapt (adaptive capacity). The results help to identify near-term actions to prioritise, as well as identify those the longer term issues.

nodes.label: Water reservoirs
nodes.description: A water reservoir is an enclosed area for the storage of water to be used at a later date. Reservoirs are an important feature of many water supply systems around the world.

nodes.label: Forecasting system
nodes.description: Weather forecasting is an important application of scientific computing that aims to predict future weather changes, especially in regards to extreme weather events. It can generate data for dozens of atmospheric and land-soil variables, including temperatures, winds, precipitation, soil moisture, and atmospheric ozone concentration.

nodes.label: earthquake
nodes.description: An earthquake is the shaking of the Earth's surface resulting from a sudden release of energy in the lithosphere that creates seismic waves.

nodes.label: Floating agricultural systems
nodes.description: Floating agriculture is a way of producing food in areas that are waterlogged for long periods of time. It is mainly aimed at adapting to increased or prolonged flooding.

nodes.label: Drought forecasting systems
nodes.description: Drought forecasting systems use models fed by climatic and atmospheric data (historical/seasonal weather patterns, real-time meteorological monitoring, and weather forecasts) to predict the probability of a drought occurring in a region or area of interest in the future (up to approximately three months). Drought forecasting systems are an important part of early warning systems, as they provide lead-time to planners for threat responses, which helps minimize drought impact risk.

nodes.label: landfilling
nodes.description: The process of depositing waste into or onto the land

nodes.label: Solar water distillation
nodes.description: Solar water distillation is the process of using the energy from sunlight to separate freshwater from salts or other contaminants.

nodes.label: Improved irrigation efficiency
nodes.description: Improving irrigation efficiency aims at minimising water use within the agricultural sector while continuing to maintain optimal crop productivity rates. Water (and energy) efficient irrigation also provides a number of environmental and socio-economic benefits. High irrigation efficiency is becoming increasingly important due to the current decrease in available water resources and growing populations that drive expansion of agricultural activities.

nodes.label: Forest fire control
nodes.description: Fire Control is defined as all activities concerned with protection of the vegetative cover and structures from destruction by fire

nodes.label: fracking
nodes.description: Hydraulic fracturing is a technique used to enable the extraction of natural gas or oil from shale and other forms of “tight” rock.

nodes.label: Leakage management in piped systems
nodes.description: Management, detection and repair of small leaks in a distribution system are critical functions of system operation and maintenance. Leak management methods can prevent or reduce leakage volume and leak detection technology can improve the ability of water utilities to respond quickly and repair leaks.

nodes.label: coseismic subsidence
nodes.description: It is the downward distributed vertical permanent ground deformation (warping) that result from earthquake displacements on a dipping (inclined) fault.

nodes.label: monitoring systems
nodes.description: A monitoring system refers to a set of tools, technologies, and processes used to continuously collect, track, and analyse data. In the context of climate change, these systems are crucial for observing changes in factors such as temperature, emissions, weather patterns, or resource use.

nodes.label: Soil remediation
nodes.description: Soil remediation refers to the strategy of managing soil to control salinity and sodicity, in order to reduce plant stress and improve productivity. Another goal is to reduce contaminants concentration.

nodes.label: climate change adaptation governance
nodes.description: Development and implementation of strategies, regulations, and initiatives to adapt to climate change

nodes.label: Seawater desalination
nodes.description: Seawater desalination is a process in which salt and other constituents are removed to produce pure water.

nodes.label: Disaster risk assessment tools
nodes.description: A qualitative or quantitative approach to determine the nature and extent of disaster risk by analysing potential hazards and evaluating existing conditions of exposure and vulnerability that together could harm people, property, services, livelihoods and the environment on which they depend.

nodes.label: terrestrial risk
nodes.description: Terrestrial means "of the earth" and relates to the ecological system that includes all living organisms and their interactions within land-based environments, such as forests, grasslands, and deserts.

nodes.label: Runoff control structures
nodes.description: Runoff control structures are designed to capture runoff during peak flows, and can function as temporary storage sites. These structures are typically built with a discharge component to slowly release water into the nearby waterway to avoid it overflowing from the storage basin. It can be artificially built, for example by excavating a large area so that it is lower than the surrounding land.

nodes.label: Climate model projections
nodes.description: Climate projections are simulations of Earth’s climate for future decades based on assumed 'scenarios' for variables such as the concentration of greenhouse gases. Climate projections are obtained by running numerical models describing the interactions between the components of the Earth’s climate, covering the entire globe or just a specific region e.g. Europe.

nodes.label: Breakwaters
nodes.description: Breakwaters are shore-parallel structures located just offshore of the surf zone. They are designed to intercept and reduce incoming wave energy at the shoreline. They thereby protect the coastline behind breakwaters. Breakwaters are generally very solid, durable structures and are considered a protection measure.

nodes.label: Drought risk mapping
nodes.description: Drought risk mapping helps identify the areas most at risk of droughts, allowing communities to plan, as well as prepare for and mitigate possible impacts. Drought risk is calculated as the probability of negative impact caused by interactions between hazard (probability of future drought events occurring based on past, current and projected drought conditions), exposure (scale of assets and population in the area) and vulnerability (probability of assets and population being affected by droughts in the area).

nodes.label: Jetties
nodes.description: Jetties are hard structures built at the banks of tidal inlets and river mouths aiming to stabilise one or both banks from shifting position and prevent large volumes of sand from filling the inlet/river mouth and preventing channel siltation. Jetties are solid and durable and are considered a protection measure.

nodes.label: Terracing
nodes.description: In agriculture, terracing refers to the technique of creating flat, stepped areas on slopes to facilitate farming. This method enhances water retention and reduces soil erosion, making it an essential practice in regions with hilly terrains.

nodes.label: liquefaction
nodes.description: Liquefaction is the term applied to the loss of strength experienced in loosely packed, saturated or close to saturated sediments at or near the ground surface.

nodes.label: Fog harvesting
nodes.description: Fogs have the potential to provide an alternative source of fresh water in dry regions and can be harvested through the use of simple and low-cost collection systems. Captured water can then be used for agricultural irrigation and domestic use. Fog harvesting provides a way of capturing vital water supplies to support farming.

nodes.label: Floating houses
nodes.description: A floating building is a building unit with a flotation system at its base, to allow it to float on water. It is common to define such a building as being "permanently moored" and not usable in navigation. Floating buildings have environmental benefits such as unsusceptibility to changes in sea level.

nodes.label: Climate change monitoring
nodes.description: A climate change monitoring system integrates satellite observations, ground-based data and forecast models to monitor and forecast changes in the weather and climate. A historical record of spot measurements is built up over time, which provides the data to enable statistical analysis and the identification of mean values, trends and variations.

nodes.label: maladaptation
nodes.description: Maladaptation is when adaptation strategies increase vulnerability to climate change impacts, rather than reduce them.

nodes.label: Bioswales
nodes.description: A bioswale is a ditch with vegetation and a porous bottom. The top layer consists of enhanced soil with plants. Below there is a layer of gravel, scoria or baked clay pellets packed in geotextile. These materials have large empty spaces, allowing the rainwater to drain off. An infiltration pipe/drainpipe is situated below the second layer. Rainfall infiltrates into the ground via the ditch and the packed layer. If the water rises above the level of the overflow, the water runs through it to the drainpipe.

nodes.label: multi-hazard early warning system
nodes.description: A multi-hazard early warning system is an integrated system which allows people to know that hazardous weather or climate events are on their way, and informs how governments, communities, and individuals can act to minimise it's impacts.

nodes.label: Cool roofs
nodes.description: A Cool Roof is a roofing system able to reflect solar heat and keep roof surfaces cool.This is due to the properties of the reflective materials used which reflect solar radiation back into the atmosphere. As the roof stays cooler, this reduces the amount of heat transferred to the building below, keeping a cooler temperature in the interior.

nodes.label: early warning system
nodes.description: An integrated single-hazard monitoring system that warns for impending extreme weather events and climate conditions, reducing the losses and damages and saving lives.

nodes.label: crop rotation
nodes.description: Crop rotation on arable land is the practice of alternating crops grown on a specific field in a planned pattern or sequence in successive crop years so that crops of the same species are not grown without interruption on the same field. In a rotation the crops are normally changed annually, but they can also be multi-annual.

nodes.label: tectonic uplift
nodes.description: Tectonic uplift is the geological process where land is raised due to tectonic forces, such as the movement of Earth's plates.

nodes.label: rainwater harvesting
nodes.description: Rainwater harvesting is defined as a method for inducing, collecting, storing and conserving local surface runoff for agriculture in arid and semi-arid regions.  Both small and large scale structures are used for rainwater harvesting collection and storage including tanks, reservoirs and dams.

nodes.label: Remote sensing
nodes.description: Remote sensing refers to the process of collecting data about an object or area without being in direct contact with it. This is typically done through satellites that capture images often using sensors that detect electromagnetic radiation (e.g., visible light, infrared, or microwave). This data can include information about vegetation, water bodies, land use, weather patterns, etc.

nodes.label: submarine landslide
nodes.description: A submarine landslide is a downslope movement of sediment or rock under the effect of gravity, which occurs when the stresses acting downslope exceed the available strength of the sediment on the slope.

nodes.label: Resilient road systems
nodes.description: Roads with lower vulnerability to climate change.

nodes.label: Artificial reefs
nodes.description: Artificial reefs have been constructed from discarded human-made materials, such as tires, concrete blocks, or even old subway cars, in areas of oceans where reefs have been depleted. Organisms such as algae and barnacles then attach to these surfaces and lay the ecological groundwork for a reef to bloom.

nodes.label: E-agriculture
nodes.description: e-Agriculture is a global community of practice that facilitates dialogue, information exchange and sharing of ideas related to the use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) for sustainable agriculture and rural development.

nodes.label: induced earthquake
nodes.description: Induced seismic ground shaking comprises non-tectonic (i.e., nonnatural) earthquakes which result from human activities that alter thestresses and strains on the Earth’s crust.

nodes.label: Coastal monitoring
nodes.description: Coastal monitoring involves collecting a variety of data in the coastal environment. Long-term monitoring builds up an evidence base to help us understand coastal processes providing information of the development of strategic shoreline management plans, coastal flood defence strategies.

nodes.label: water management sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the distribution, treatment, and conservation of water resources.

nodes.label: River restoration
nodes.description: Rivers are dynamic by nature as they carve their own course, distribute sediments and spill onto flood plains during flood events. Ecological river restoration involves ecological, spatial and physical management practices with the aim of returning rivers to their natural state.  Common restoration techniques include reconnecting rivers with floodplains, reestablishment of the river’s meandering form with no barriers along its banks (i.e. removal of built-up embankments), and stabilising surrounding soil to reduce sedimentation and erosion (i.e. bed fixation).

nodes.label: Artificial lowering of glacial lakes
nodes.description: The artificial lowering of glacial lakes is the process of draining water from those vulnerable to overflowing by digging a canal from the lake to a nearby river. Drainage reduces water level and decreases pressure on moraine dams. This in turn reduces the risk of burst events (i.e., GLOFs).

nodes.label: elevated buildings
nodes.description: An elevated building, with regards to flooding, is a building that is raised on columns (or stilts) so that the floor level is higher than the potential level of the flood water.

nodes.label: Soil moisture conservation
nodes.description: Soil moisture conservation aims to minimise the amount of water lost from the soils through evaporation (water loss directly from the soil) and transpiration (water loss occurring through the plants). Preserving soil moisture is important means to maintain the necessary water for agricultural production, and also helps minimise irrigation needs of the crops. This is especially important in areas where rainwater and/or groundwater resources for irrigation are scarce or decreasing due to climate change.

nodes.label: Disaster-resilient buildings
nodes.description: It refers to buildings that are built to withstand and quickly recover from various hazards, including natural disasters.

nodes.label: Resilient transport systems
nodes.description: Transport system resilience is the sector’s capacity to deal with, adapt to and recover from severe and sudden shocks. The recovery capacity determines the time needed to return to business as usual and can be improved through adaptation measures.

nodes.label: Cliff stabilisation
nodes.description: Cliff stabilisation is a form of soft engineering, using natural processes to protect the shoreline against flooding and erosion. Stabilisation techniques are used to limit the amount of erosion and the potential for landslides,collapse and falling rocks.

nodes.label: Resilient rail systems
nodes.description: Resilience of railway transport system is defined as the ability of a railway system to provide effective services in normal conditions, as well as to resist, absorb, accommodate and recover quickly from disruptions or disasters.

nodes.label: landslide
nodes.description: Landslide is the downslope movement of soil, rock and organic materials under the effects of gravity, which occurs when the gravitational driving forces exceed the frictional resistance of the material resisting on the slope.

nodes.label: crop insurance
nodes.description: Agricultural producers can purchase crop insurance for protection against climate-related losses from extreme events like flooding, drought, and storms.

nodes.label: Constructed wetlands
nodes.description: Constructed wetlands protect coastal communities during flooding by absorbing wave energy or storing excess water. In the later, it is a shallow basin filled with some sort of filler material (substrate), usually sand or gravel, and planted with vegetation tolerant of saturated conditions to mimic the function of mangrove forest or salt marshes. In the context of water purification, constructed wetlands make use of the natural purification processes of vegetation, soils and microbes to remove contaminants from discharge and improve water quality.

nodes.label: Flood forecasting systems
nodes.description: A flood warning system is a way of detecting threatening events in advance. This enables the public to be alerted in advance and can undertake appropriate responses to minimise the impact of the events.

nodes.label: Sea walls
nodes.description: Seawalls are hard engineered structures with a primary function to prevent further erosion of the shoreline. They are built parallel to the shore and aim to hold or prevent erosion and, secondary, function as coastal flood defences.

nodes.label: Hazard mapping
nodes.description: Hazard Mapping is the process of establishing where and to what extent particular phenomena are likely to pose a threat to people,property, infrastructure and economic activities. Hazard mapping represents the results of a hazard assessment on a map, showing the frequency/probability of occurrences of various magnitudes or duration.
